courseTitle: Cell Structure and Function: Eukaryotes, Prokaryotes, and Viruses

pageData.text: All living things are composed of cells, and all cells arise from preexisting cells. While some organisms consist of a single cell, others are made of thousands of cells with specialized structures and functions. In this lab exercise, students explore the structure and function of eukaryotic and prokaryotic cells and viruses.In Activity 1, potatoes are used to study how the relationship between surface area and volume influences into and out of a cell. In Activity 2, a semipermeable membrane is used to examine how the size and concentration of molecules affect and diffusion across . In Activity 3, a cell or virus is constructed by selecting structures and organelles from the Cell/Virus Components Tracing Guide. The cell or virus is then described, based on the structures and characteristics chosen, and verified using a .

pageData.text: There are many different causes of illness. Some, like the common cold or smallpox, are caused by viruses; others, like malaria, are caused by microscopic organisms; and then there are diseases like cancer that are caused by our own cells. Cancer is a disease caused by the uncontrolled division of abnormal cells in the body. Modern science has eradicated, and allows us to cure, many diseases; however, in the United States, cancer is on the rise. It is predicted that by 2040, the number of new cancer cases per year will rise to 29.5 million. Will science ever eliminate cancer as a public health concern? According to Harvard Public Health (2022), the answer is no: it is not possible to eradicate cancer. Unlike virus-caused diseases, which can be prevented by a vaccine, cancers are not caused by a single factor. The risk of developing some cancers can be reduced by making healthy lifestyle choices (i.e., not smoking and exercising regularly); however, unfortunately, most cancers are caused by environmental factors and genetics. Harvard Public Health (2022) suggests that instead of focusing on eradicating cancer, the focus should be placed on its prevention, early detection, and individualized treatments.
ReferenceDrexler, M. (2022). The cancer miracle isn’t a cure. Harvard Public Health. https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/magazine/magazine_article/the-cancer-miracle-isnt-a-cure-its-prevention/

pageData.text: Living things must be able to take in nutrients and eliminate waste in order to survive. These functions are facilitated on the cellular level by a semipermeable (selectively permeable) , a structure that surrounds and defines each cell. This barrier allows molecules of a certain size or charge to pass through it, while blocking larger or differently charged molecules. Some molecules—such as water, oxygen, and carbon dioxide—can move freely across the cell membrane’s lipid bilayer. These molecules move into and out of the cell by , which can be defined as the net movement of molecules (or ions) down a concentration gradient from a region of higher concentration to a region of lower concentration.

pageData.subTitle: Surface-to-Volume Ratio
pageData.text: As cells grow, their volume increases faster than their surface area; therefore, the surface area-to-volume ratio gets smaller. Some cells, like neurons, are very large, but the elongated nature of their axons allows them to have a large surface-to-volume ratio. Molecules will pass more efficiently in and out of a cell with a larger surface-to-volume ratio. A cell with a small surface-to-volume ratio will require more oxygen and nutrients than can pass through the cell membrane, and may also produce more CO2 and other wastes than it can effectively secrete. Cells with large surface-to-volume ratios can take in the required amounts of oxygen and still release wastes, as required for survival.

pageData.subTitle: Cell Membranes, Osmosis, and Diffusion
pageData.text: Diffusion across a semipermeable membrane, such as a cell membrane, is subject to certain conditions. Smaller molecules can pass freely from one side of the membrane to the other; larger molecules, however, are restricted. Four main factors determine the rate of diffusion of molecules or ions across a membrane:

text: The steepness of the concentration gradient. The greater the difference between the concentrations on opposite sides of the membrane, the higher the rate of diffusion.
Temperature. Molecules and ions have more kinetic energy at higher temperatures. Molecules move more rapidly, so diffusion is faster.
The surface area of the membrane. The greater the surface area, the faster the rate of diffusion. This is because more molecules or ions can cross the membrane at any point in time.
The type of molecule or ion diffusing. Large molecules tend to diffuse more slowly.

pageData.text: is a special type of ; it is the diffusion of water molecules across a selectively permeable membrane. The four factors listed also apply to the diffusion of water during osmosis. Net movement of water molecules in osmosis is to the side of the membrane having the higher concentration of solute molecules.Much of the cytoplasm of a cell is water, but there are numerous molecules dissolved in that water, so the movement of water in and out of cells can be complex. If the cell is surrounded by solute-free pure water, the concentration of water is actually lower inside the cell and the pure water will move in. If the cell is in very salty water, the concentration of water may be higher inside, causing water to move out of the cell. If the cell is in very salty water, the concentration of solutes may be higher outside, causing water to move out of the cell.

The terms <button class='glossary-text'>hypertonic</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>hypotonic</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>isotonic</button> are used to compare different solutions. If the solutions have the same concentration of solute, they are called isotonic (iso-, “same”). When two solutions have different concentrations of a solute, the one with more solute is called hypertonic (hyper-, “above”), and the one with less solute is called hypotonic (hypo-, “below”). It is important to note that, whereas a hypertonic solution contains more solute than the solution with which it is being compared, it also has less water. A hypotonic solution has less solute but more water. This is important to keep in mind, because it is the movement of water that occurs in osmosis. The water will move from the solution in which it is more concentrated to the solution in which it is less concentrated. In other words, water will move from the hypotonic solution to the hypertonic one. In Figures 1 and 2, the large, black dots represent the solute molecules and the small, open circles represent the water molecules. The vertical centerline represents a semipermeable membrane.

In Figure 1, the concentration of solute molecules is higher on the left side of the membrane, so the left side is to the right side. The right side is to the left side.In Figure 2, the left and right sides are at equilibrium and are to each other. The concentration of molecules on both sides of the membrane is equal. is the measure of a solution’s tendency to take up water when separated from pure water by a selectively permeable membrane. A solution’s osmotic pressure is proportional to its solute concentration; the greater the solute concentration, the greater the osmotic pressure and, therefore, the greater the tendency for the solution to take up water. In isotonic solutions, water diffuses across the membrane from one solution to another at an equal rate in both directions. There is no net osmotic movement of water and no net osmotic pressure.In theory, water would continue to flow from a hypotonic solution to a hypertonic solution until they became isotonic to each other.

image.altText: Figure 1: A square divided in half. The left has 6 large black circles and 6 small white circles; the right has 2 large black circles and 6 small white circles.
Figure 2: A square divided in half. Each half has 4 large black circles and 6 small white circles.

pageData.text: However, in many situations, as the water flows to the hypertonic solution it causes pressure to build up. Once this pressure is equal to the osmotic pressure, the flow of water is equal in both directions. Under these conditions, a hypertonic solution and a hypotonic solution can be maintained. Turgor pressure in plant cells results from the <button class='glossary-text'>cell wall’s</button> opposition to osmotic pressure.

pageData.subTitle: Cell Types and Viruses
pageData.text: Earth’s atmosphere was dramatically different 3 billion years ago. Prokaryotes were the dominant, and possibly only, organisms on Earth. Scientists theorize that oxygen levels were low until photosynthetic prokaryotes called cyanobacteria became abundant. Remember that oxygen is a byproduct of photosynthesis. Massive populations of cyanobacteria caused a dramatic increase in the amount of oxygen in the Earth’s atmosphere 2.2 billion to 2.5 billion years ago. This period is referred to as the Oxygen Revolution because high levels of oxygen allowed for rapid evolution of cellular metabolism, in particular, the ways in which cells acquire energy and nutrients. Many organisms evolved to use the now abundant oxygen for cellular respiration. These organisms are called . Some prokaryotic groups remained , not requiring oxygen for cellular respiration. Anaerobes live primarily in locations lacking oxygen, such as around hydrothermal vents in deep undersea canyons.Whereas means of energy consumption drove the early evolution of organisms, later evolution dramatically altered cellular structure and function, leading to even greater biodiversity. Current scientific investigations of evolutionary history study the progression from simple prokaryotes to complex eukaryotes.

All cells have internal and external features (see ). The plasma membrane of the cell separates the cytoplasm and organelles from the extracellular environment. All cells are surrounded by a semipermeable plasma membrane that regulates the movement of molecules in and out of the cell. Most are composed of a bilayer of lipids with fatty acid tails. The membranes of Archaeans also include molecules called isoprene units, which are bound to the lipid components of the membrane.Most prokaryotes and some eukaryotes have another protective layer, called the , outside the cell membrane. Eukaryotes have a variety of cell walls. Protists can have cell walls made of cellulose or silica. Fungi have cell walls made of chitin. Organisms in kingdom Plantae have cell walls made of cellulose, whereas those in kingdom Animalia lack cell walls.

pageData.text: Bacteria have made of molecules called peptidoglycans, as well as a lipid bilayer that makes up the . Many bacteria can be classified as gram-positive or gram-negative, a naming system that originates from the method of staining used to distinguish different classes of bacteria based on the distinct properties of their cell walls. Gram-positive cell walls are much thicker than gram-negative cell walls and contain additional complex structures made of sugars and amino acids that assist in membrane transport, regulation, cell growth, and morphology. Gram-negative cells have a thinner peptidoglycan layer as well as a space, the periplasm, between the inner cell membrane and an outer cell membrane. The outer layer contains fats, sugars, and proteins. These extra components make gram-negative bacteria resistant to lysozyme and many antibiotics.The prokaryotic cell contains suspended in the gel-like cytoplasm. The cytoplasm contains other organelles that carry out cellular processes. More complex cells have more complex organelles.

Most prokaryotes (i.e., Eubacteria and archaea) have a cell wall, cell membrane, cytoplasm, , and circular DNA. Prokaryotes exist in a variety of shapes, and some have means of locomotion. Most modern eukaryotes (i.e., the kingdoms Protists, Fungi, Plants, and Animals) possess a membrane-bounded containing double-stranded DNA; they also contain ribosomes, , and vesicles, , and . The cytoskeleton is made up of structural proteins—such as actin, myosin, and tubulin—organized in a dynamic network of interacting filaments, fibers, and microtubules. The cytoskeleton provides the internal structure of the cell and participates in cell locomotion and division. Further, some eukaryotic cells have specialized organelles for photosynthesis (), division (), water collection and food digestion (), and locomotion (cilia, flagella, pseudopodia).

Unlike eukaryotes, bacteria, archaea, and viruses are acellular, and there is ongoing debate over whether they can be classified as living organisms. Viruses generally consist of enclosed in a lipid-protein capsule, or . Some viruses also have an envelope surrounding the capsid. The envelope is composed of proteins, lipids, and sugars derived from the virus and the host cell. Specific proteins in the envelope allow the virus to identify and infect specific cell types. Viruses lack reproductive machinery; to replicate, they must infect a suitable host cell and “hijack” the host’s replication machinery. Viral genomes consist of either DNA or RNA and can be segmented or unsegmented. If the genetic material is single-stranded, it is referred to as a positive strand or a negative strand, depending on the direction in which the replication enzymes read the genetic code.It can be challenging to distinguish all the features and characteristics of a type of organism or virus; however, a can be used to facilitate this process. A dichotomous key is a tool for identifying items (in this case, cells or viruses) based on a series of choices between pairs of descriptors that refer to the cell/virus under investigation. With each choice, the user is directed to another choice, ultimately leading to one that definitively identifies the cell/virus.

pageData.question: Viruses lack reproductive machinery; in order to replicate they must infect a suitable host cell and ______.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Viruses lack reproductive machinery; in order to replicate they must infect a suitable host cell and use the host’s replication machinery.

pageData.question: Some viruses have single-stranded genetic material that is considered either positive or negative. What determines if this material is a positive strand or a negative strand?

the direction from which the genetic material enters a host cell
the number of cells the virus can infect with the genetic material
whether the genetic material is DNA or RNA
whether the strand starts with an adenosine or a guanine nucleotide

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. Start Activity 1 by preparing potato blocks and an iodine solution. Then, place the blocks in a cup and cover the blocks with the iodine solution. Soak the blocks in the solution for 80 minutes. Then, remove the blocks from the solution and cut them in half lengthwise to measure the size of the cross section. Finally, measure the distance permeated by the iodine solution and the area of the unstained cross section. Start Activity 2 by preparing sucrose solutions, then label 3 plastic cups. Fill the cups with their designated sucrose solutions and dialysis tubing with their designated sucrose solutions. Next, measure the volume of each of 3 tubes by water displacement. Place each tube into its designated cup and allow them to sit in the cup solutions for 1 hour. Then measure the new volume and determine the tonicity of the cup solution for each tube.

In Activity 1, you will model the effect of surface-area-to-volume ratio on cellular <button class='glossary-text'>diffusion</button> using potatoes cubes and an iodine-potassium iodide (IKI) solution.
Read the activity thoroughly, and become familiar with the materials in conjuction with the activity before beginning.

Prepare potato blocks.
  1. Peel one potato.
  2. Use the metric ruler, knife, and cutting board to prepare potato blocks of the dimensions seen in Table 2 below.
  3. Use a second potato if necessary.
  4. Store the potato blocks on a damp paper towel until ready to use.

Prepare iodine solution.
  1. Label a 10-oz cup “IKI.”
  2. Use the graduated cylinder to measure 150 mL of tap water, and add it to the cup.
  3. Use the graduated cylinder to measure 30 mL of IKI solution, and add it to the cup.

typeBefore.title: Why Cells Are Small (8 steps)

pageData.text: Place all the prepared potato blocks loosely into two empty 10-oz cups. First, place the larger blocks into the cup, and then arrange some of the smaller blocks around them. Try to avoid having one full side of a block against another block. If necessary, stack some of the smaller cubes on top of the larger cubes, but do not have two sides flat against one another. The iodine solution must be able to permeate all sides of the potato blocks.
Pour the IKI solution over the potato blocks in the two cups. Make sure all the potato blocks are completely submerged in the solution.
Allow the blocks to soak in the solution for 80 minutes.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Using a spoon, scoop the blocks out of the solution and place them onto a paper towel.
Use a knife to cut each block in half lengthwise.
Note: Cut the 2 x 2 x 1 cm block in half to make two 2 x 1 x 1 cm blocks, and cut the 0.5 x 0.5 x 2 cm block in half to make two 0.5 x 0.5 x 1 cm blocks.
Use the metric ruler to measure the size of the cross section, the distance penetrated by the black iodine solution, and the size of the white, unstained area.

pageData.desc: How to Measure the Volume of a Cube

pageData.text: Record the results in Data Table 1a in the "Observations" section on page 20.
Complete the calculation in Data Table 1b.
Record the distance to the nearest centimeter (cm) and two significant digits (e.g., 1.25 cm).

In Activity 2, you will examine how the size and concentration of molecules effects movement across the <button class='glossary-text'>cell membrane</button>; dialysis tubing will serve as a semipermeable membrane for model cells placed in various sucrose solutions. You will then use your observations to classify these solutions as <button class='glossary-text'>hypertonic</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>hypotonic</button>, or <button class='glossary-text'>isotonic</button>.
Read the activity thoroughly and become familiar with the materials in conjuction with the activity before beginning.
Wash all graduated cylinders, plastic cups, spoons, and beakers that were used in Activity 1 with soap and water before using them in this activity.

Prepare solutions of 40% sucrose and 20% sucrose.
  1. Label one 250-mL beaker “40% sucrose” and another 250-mL beaker “20% sucrose” with the grease pencil.
  2. Add the contents of one 100-g sucrose packet to the “40% sucrose” beaker. Note the level of the sucrose relative to the graduations on the beaker.
  3. Add half the contents of the second sucrose packet to the “20% sucrose” beaker. Adjust the amount of sucrose so that it reaches the level that is half of that in the “40% sucrose” beaker. The 20% sucrose is an approximate concentration.
  4. Add 250 mL tap water to each beaker. It may be necessary to use heated tap water to dissolve the sucrose faster. Stir the solutions with the spoon until all the sucrose is dissolved. The solutions should be clear and colorless.
  5. Add 10 drops of red food coloring to the 20% sucrose solution.

typeBefore.title: Cell Membranes, Osmosis, and Diffusion (5 steps)

pageData.text: Label three plastic cups “A,” “B,” and “C” for each treatment with the grease pencil.

If the 40% solution was heated during the preparation, allow the solution to cool to room temperature before adding the dialysis tubing. Both solutions should be at a similar temperature for this experiment.

The experimental design for the treatments is as follows:
  1. Cup A: 20% sucrose solution in cup, 20% sucrose solution in the dialysis tube.
  2. Cup B: 20% sucrose solution in cup, 40% sucrose solution in the dialysis tube.
  3. Cup C: 40% sucrose solution in cup, 20% sucrose solution in the dialysis tube.
Label three weigh boats “A,” “B,” and “C” for each treatment with the grease pencil.
Pour about 100 mL of 20% sucrose solution into cups A and B only.
Pour about 100 mL of 40% sucrose solution into cup C.

typeBefore.title: Preparing the Dialysis Tubing (16 steps)

pageData.text: Fill a clean plastic cup with water.
Place the dialysis tubing in the water.
Allow the dialysis tubing to remain in the water for at least 30 seconds.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Remove the dialysis tubing from the water.
Gently roll the end of the tubing between your index finger and thumb. This should cause the dialysis tubing to open.

Continue rolling the tubing down its length until the tubing is completely open. Use a dialysis tubing clip to seal off one end of the tubing by twisting the bottom inch of the tubing and snapping the clip closed. An alternative to using the dialysis tubing clip is to tie a simple knot on one end of the dialysis tubing as shown in Figure 4. This knot should be as close to the end as possible. Use the 25-mL graduated cylinder to pour 10 mL of 20% sucrose solution into the dialysis tube.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: A simple knot tied on one end of a piece of dialysis tubing

pageData.text: Carefully remove almost all the air from the space above the solution, leaving only a small bubble, so the tubing will float in the dialysis solution. To expel air, gently squeeze upward with the thumb and index finger of one hand while supporting the filled tubing with the other hand.

Use a dialysis tubing clip to seal off the top of the tubing. Twist the top inch of the tubing and snap the clip closed to seal the tubing. As noted before, an alternative to using the clip is to tie a simple knot at the top end of the tubing as shown in Figure 5. Note: The tubes in treatments “A” and “C” will have red solution inside them.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: Entire piece of dialysis tubing, containing a solution mixture, knotted at both ends

pageData.text: Rinse the outside of the dialysis tubing with water, and gently blot dry with a paper towel.

Measure the volume of each solution in each dialysis tube by displacement:
  1. Add 80 mL of tap water to the 100-mL graduated cylinder.
  2. Drop tube “A” into the graduated cylinder, and make sure the solution inside the tubing is completely submerged.
  3. Observe the new water level, and record the value as “initial volume” in Data Table 2.
  4. Remove the tubing from the graduated cylinder, and discard the water. Squeeze any excess water out from the ends of the tubing, and place the tubing in its designated weigh boat.
Perform Steps 1-10 for tubes “B” and “C” using the 40% sucrose solution for “B” and the 20% one for “C.”
Transfer the tubes into the labeled cups containing the appropriate sucrose solutions, making sure they are completely submerged, and start the timer.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Allow the tubes to sit in the cups for 1 hour.
Remove each tube from the cup, squeeze any excess water out from the tubing ends, and place the tubes into their appropriately labeled weigh boats.

Measure the new volume of the solution in each tube.
  1. Add 80 mL of tap water to the 100-mL graduated cylinder.
  2. Drop tube “A” into the graduated cylinder, and make sure it is completely submerged.
  3. Observe the new water level, and record the value as “final volume” in Data Table 2.
  4. Remove the tubing from the graduated cylinder, squeeze any excess water out from the ends of the tubing, and place the tube in its designated weigh boat. Discard the water.
  5. Perform Steps a-d for tubes “B” and “C”.

Based on the results, determine whether the solution in each tube was <button class='glossary-text'>isotonic</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>hypotonic</button>, or <button class='glossary-text'>hypertonic</button> to the solution in the cup.

text: Carefully pour all liquids down the drain, flushing with excess tap water.
Dispose of the potatoes, weigh boats, and dialysis tubing in the household trash.
Wash and dry the spoons, beaker, graduated cylinder, knife, cutting board, and cups.
Store remaining materials in the original kit bags or equipment set.
Clean the work area, and wash your hands.

pageData.text: In Activity 3, you will design your own prokaryotic cell, eukaryotic cell, and virus. You will then use a <button class='glossary-text'>dichotomous key</button> to identify the species of each.
Collect the pencil, colored pencils, and paper, then open the Cell/Virus Components Tracing Guide.
Clear enough space to be able to draw.

typeBefore.title: Designing a Prokaryote (8 steps)

pageData.text: Select a cell shape (1-3) on the Cell/Virus Components Tracing Guide, and draw it on the paper. This shape represents the prokaryote’s <button class='glossary-text'>cell membrane</button>.
There are no right or wrong choices as long as the guidelines are followed. After the cell has been created, it will be identified using the <button class='glossary-text'>dichotomous key</button>.
Most prokaryotes have <button class='glossary-text'>cell walls</button>. Draw a thick line around the cell membrane to represent the cell wall.

Draw a magnified view of a small section of the cell membrane and cell wall (example, 35). Make a tiny box around this section, and draw lines connecting this box to a larger box. The larger box is called an inset, and it is a magnified view of the contents of the smaller box.

Choose from among the following options: a basic cell membrane (38) or a cell membrane with isoprene units (39). If the prokaryote has a basic cell membrane, draw either the gram-positive (36) or gram-negative (37) image in the inset box. These insets include representations of both the cell wall and cell membrane.
Add the standard prokaryotic cellular components inside the cell. Remember that prokaryotes have circular DNA (9) and <button class='glossary-text'>ribosomes</button> (11).
Some prokaryotes possess a means of locomotion. A single flagellum (19), two polar flagella (20), or multiple flagella (21) may be selected and added to the drawing.
Color the remaining space inside the cell to represent the cytoplasm and cytoskeleton.
Label all parts of the prokaryote.

typeBefore.title: Designing a Eukaryote (8 steps)

pageData.text: Select a cell shape (1-8) on the Cell/Virus Components Tracing Guide, and draw it on the blank paper. This shape represents the eukaryotic cell membrane.
Draw a magnified view of a section of the cell membrane. Draw the basic cell membrane (38) with a magnified inset box.
Decide whether the cell has a cell wall. If it does have a cell wall, draw a thick line around the shape or cell membrane. Cells that lack a rigid structure cannot have cell walls.

Add the standard eukaryotic cell components to the cell. Be sure to include double-stranded DNA inside a nuclear membrane (10), <button class='glossary-text'>ribosomes</button> (11), <button class='glossary-text'>mitochondria</button> (12), <button class='glossary-text'>endoplasmic reticulum</button> (14), <button class='glossary-text'>Golgi apparatus</button> (15), and <button class='glossary-text'>lysosomes</button> and vesicles (16). Refer to the <button class='resource-text'>Cell Components Chart (Table 1)</button> to match each organelle with its function.
Some eukaryotic cells also have other internal organelles. One or more organelles can be added. Options include (13), (17), and (18). Refer to the (Table 1) to match each organelle with its function.

Some eukaryotic cells possess a means of locomotion, which can be added to the cell drawing. The amoeboid shape (8), which has no rigid structure, can only be paired with the pseudopod (22). If any other cell shape is selected, cilia or flagella may be added. Cilia (23) may be found around all or part of the perimeter of the cell. Alternatively, the cell may have one flagellum (19), two flagella (20), or many flagella (21).
Color the remaining space inside the cell to represent the cytoplasm and cytoskeleton.
Label all the parts of the eukaryotic cell.

typeBefore.title: Designing a Virus (3 steps)

pageData.text: Select the shape of the viral <button class='glossary-text'>capsid</button> from among the choices on the Cell/Virus Components Tracing Guide: polyhedral (24), helical (26), or complex “tailed polyhedral” (28). Draw the selected capsid shape on the paper.

Certain polyhedral and helical viruses have an envelope. If the capsid is polyhedral or helical, an envelope may be added. The envelope is represented by a thick line around the capsid (as shown in 25 and 27).

Add a viral genome (29-34). First, choose either DNA or RNA. Then, decide whether the genomic material is single- or double-stranded. If it is single-stranded, it is important to note direction in which the genetic information is read by replication enzymes. Draw a small “plus” sign (+) or “minus” sign (–) beside the genomic material. Is the <button class='glossary-text'>genetic material</button> segmented or not segmented?

typeBefore.title:
B
Identifying the Cell or Virus Created (4 steps)

pageData.text: Use the Dichotomous Keys to determine whether the drawing depicts a prokaryote, a eukaryote, or a virus.

Find the most similar cell or virus by starting at Number 1 and following the instructions until an example of the cell or virus is found. The drawing will not indicate whether the cell wall is made of chitin, cellulose, or silica, but other indicators should help the decision process to properly identify the cell or virus.
Label each drawing with the most similar cell or virus example that is found based upon the Background text and the Dichotomous Keys.

Label the approximate sizes of the cells and viruses. Viruses range from 20-200 nanometers (nm). Bacteria and archaea in the given examples are between 0.1 micrometers (μm) and 15 μm in diameter, and may be up to 200 μm long. The eukaryotic cells in this exercise range from 2 μm to 100 μm in diameter.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. Start Activity 1 by preparing potato blocks and an iodine solution. Then, place the blocks in a cup and cover the blocks with the iodine solution. Soak the blocks in the solution for 80 minutes. Then, remove the blocks from the solution and cut them in half lengthwise to measure the size of the cross section. Finally, measure the distance permeated by the iodine solution and the area of the unstained cross section. Start Activity 2 by preparing sucrose solutions, then label 3 plastic cups. Fill the cups with their designated sucrose solutions and dialysis tubing with their designated sucrose solutions. Next, measure the volume of each of 3 tubes by water displacement. Place each tube into its designated cup and allow them to sit in the cup solutions for 1 hour. Then measure the new volume and determine the tonicity of the cup solution for each tube.

pageData.content: How to Measure the Volume of a Cube

data.title: Aerobic
data.content: Describes organisms that evolved to use oxygen for cellular respiration

data.title: Anaerobic
data.content: Describes organisms that evolved to not require oxygen for cellular respiration

data.title: Capsid
data.content: The lipid-protein capsule that surrounds a virus's genetic material

data.title: Cell membrane
data.content: The lipid bilayer that separates the intracellular components of a cell from the extracellular space, and allows transport in and out of the cell

data.title: Cell wall
data.content: The external organelle that provides rigidity and protects the cell from its environment

data.title: Centrioles
data.content: Microtubular structures that participate in chromosome separation during cell division

data.title: Chloroplasts
data.content: The eukaryotic organelles that carry out photosynthesis to produce energy for the cell in the form of ATP

data.title: Dichotomous key
data.content: A tool for identifying items based on a series of choices between pairs of descriptors that refer to the items under investigation

data.title: Diffusion
data.content: The net movement of molecules or ions down a concentration gradient

data.title: Endoplasmic reticulum (ER)
data.content: The smooth er stores lipids, assists in movement of newly synthesized proteins, and houses important enzymes; some ribosomes are attached to the rough er, which participates in folding and sorting of newly synthesized proteins

data.title: Genetic material
data.content: The instructions for making proteins

data.title: Golgi apparatus
data.content: The eukaryotic organelle that packages and processes proteins and lipids for transport to designated locations in the cell

data.title: Hypertonic
data.content: The solution with the higher solute concentration relative to another solution

data.title: Hypotonic
data.content: The solution with the lower solute concentration relative to another solution

data.title: Isotonic
data.content: A solution with a solute concentration equal to that of another solution

data.title: Lysosomes
data.content: The eukaryotic organelles that digest foreign materials and unwanted organelles in the cytoplasm

data.title: Mitochondria
data.content: The eukaryotic organelles that produce energy for the cell in the form of ATP

data.title: Nucleus
data.content: The eukaryotic organelle that houses genetic material

data.title: Osmosis
data.content: A special type of diffusion in which water molecules diffuse across a selectively permeable membrane

data.title: Osmotic pressure
data.content: The measure of a solution's tendency to take up water when separated from pure water by a selectively permeable membrane

data.title: Ribosomes
data.content: Cell organelles that translate messenger RNAs into proteins; ribosomes can be free in the cytoplasm or bound to the endoplasmic reticulum (ER)

data.title: Vacuoles
data.content: The eukaryotic organelles that provide storage space for food or water
